Cure to Evil
Mirrond
Summary:

    All for One has did his absolute best to change his son into a perfect villain. The skills, the contacts, the money. Even the quirk. Now that he officially retired to focus on his family (namely, his beloved if slightly intimidating wife and absolutely adorable adopted daughter that he only had to destroy one yakuza clan to obtain - a bargain, really) he expects his son to become his heir. To have All Might tremble in fear.

    Except, Izuku's definition of villainy sounds oddly antiheroic. Surely, he'll come around eventually. Right?

Notes:

(See the end of the work for notes and other works inspired by this one.)
Chapter 1: The Arrival
Notes:

    The story is finished. I just need to publish it all. It's honestly already fully done on the FF.net, but I decided to share it further. Especially as it's actually not a sequel (more like alternative universe thing) the Ties that Bind is doing fabulously. And yes, it'll be published here as well.

(See the end of the chapter for more notes.)
Chapter Text

UA was THE hero school. The most important, the most famous, and so on. UA produced hundreds of pro heroes in the past, including close to half of the current top ten. It was even the alma mater of All Might, the greatest of all heroes and the Symbol of Peace. 

It was a dream. Midoriya Izuku‚Äôs dream. For many, many years he dreamed of being able to walk its halls and training areas. He loved the heroes, especially All Might! His mom once told him to just open an All Might-themed museum, he had THAT much limited edition merch laying around at home. 

Finally, he managed to realize this dream and got into UA. With many prospective heroes, each of them armed with a wonderful quirk and an unyielding desire to make the world a better place. And a seriously sleep-deprived teacher that was also an underground hero that he happened to be a fan of. 

Midoriya Izuku sets the volume to the max and starts speaking. 

‚ÄúMy name is Legion, and we are the League of Villains.‚Äù He announces, the last of his comrades exiting Kurogiri behind him. ‚ÄúWe‚Äôve decided to interrupt your training exercise in order to kill the Symbol of Peace. Although, it seems he‚Äôs absent.‚Äù 

Unfortunately, Midoriya is the only one to appreciate the level of irony that his life is operating on. He is even wearing his favourite All Might hoodie.

Eraserhead shouts to Thirteen to get the students out and then charges down the stairs. A tactical mistake. Sure, there are only a few villains in the USJ main plaza. Sure, they all look barely older than the shocked students crowding next to the entrance. But he is still severely underestimating the people that broke into UA. 

‚ÄúKurogiri, scatter the students.‚Äù Izuku commands, his mask changing his voice. True to his villain‚Äôs name, he set it to change his voice every few seconds. The initial announcement was the only thing he would say with his true voice during the attack. ‚ÄúDecay and Vampire, intercept.‚Äù 

His best friend and his probably-not-a-girlfriend leap forward, engaging a pro-hero in melee combat. Knife and disintegration versus combat scarf and a lot of combat experience. 

Izuku is worried. Extremely worried. Eraserhead is an expert in capture and can deactivate quirks merely by looking at you. He is as famous as an underground hero could get. Thankfully the mask stops Izuku from stuttering and making other noises that are seriously unbecoming of an aspiring criminal mastermind.

On the other hand, it is a horrible match-up for the underground hero. Vampire fights de facto quirkless, and is very good at it. Decay‚Äôs quirk requires five finger contact and is potent enough to end the fight in a single touch - and with Vampire there, Eraserhead can‚Äôt keep it offline constantly, as it would allow the shapeshifting villain to blindside him. 

However, Eraserhead is still a professional hero, with many tricks up his sleeve! He has that object resembling a scarf, that is clearly a very advanced and skill-based capture weapon! It had to take years to master it to this level, and...

‚ÄúLegion.‚Äù Kurogiri appears out of nowhere, interrupting Izuku‚Äôs mumbling (thank god for the voice alteration thing). There is a lot of soot on the warper‚Äôs body armor. ‚ÄúThirteen is incapacitated. The Ingenium‚Äôs brother got out. I sent all the students from the list to the ambush site, but one of them‚Ä¶‚Äù 

‚ÄúYes, I can see him.‚Äù Izuku replies, feeling the incoming headache as clean as day. The explosions and ‚ÄòDIE!‚Äô screams are rather noticeable. He didn‚Äôt intend to fight his old bully during the attack. It would hurt Kacchan much more to be teleported away and safely incapacitated by the second team. With ego as fragile as his, treating him as if he wasn‚Äôt worthy of attention would be‚Ä¶ crushing. But since he wants to do it so much‚Ä¶ 

‚ÄúBAKUGOU, STOP!‚Äù Eraserhead shouts. He could have just as well tried bargaining with a landslide (its intelligence level and attention spans were comparable with Izuku‚Äôs quirkist bully). 

He goes for the head, of course. Starting with a punch. Straight one. With his right arm. Like always. Izuku grabs it and throws Kacchan over his head, drawing a knife. It is stopped centimeters away from his old bully‚Äôs face with Eraserhead‚Äôs capture scarf, extended to the max. 

‚ÄúYou really are a great hero, Eraserhead.‚Äù Izuku announces, while Vampire stabs the now defenseless teacher in his right side. Secretly he is relieved - the hand moved on his own, he didn‚Äôt plan to almost murder a kid. That would go against the League‚Äôs long-term goals.

Kacchan has enough situational awareness to use his explosions to escape from the trap. 

Decay grabs the underground hero‚Äôs head with all but one of his fingers and rams it into the pavement. Tenko‚Äôs love for excessive violence is there all along, although he is kind enough to not overdo it. And sticks to the plan. 

‚ÄúI wouldn‚Äôt move if I were you, Eraserhead.‚Äù Izuku announces. The teacher halts his attempts at struggling, and stares at him. ‚ÄúDecay‚Äôs quirk is a five point finger matter disintegration. He has all but a single finger on your head. If you move too much and make the fifth one touch you‚Ä¶‚Äù He shrugs. Hopefully this will be enough, he isn‚Äôt here to kill Eraserhead. 

‚ÄúOh, and thank you for distracting your teacher with your antics‚Ä¶‚Äù He turns towards his former bully. He wants to savour the moment. ‚Äú... Kacchan.‚Äù 

The look on Bakugou‚Äôs face is priceless when the recognition settles in. The positive side of being officially dead (together with all your loved ones) is that you don‚Äôt need to hide your name when you turn to villainy. 

‚ÄúD‚Ä¶ DEKU?!‚Äù And now he is reminded why he hates Kacchan so much. If he didn‚Äôt tailor his plan explicitly to avoid non pro-hero casualties, he would have sent Tenko after him. Izuku didn‚Äôt think that it was possible. But somehow Kacchan got worse when he wasn‚Äôt looking. Unbelievable. 

‚ÄúMustard, gas him.‚Äù The last member of the party pulls up a support item resembling a flamethrower and covers the charging student in poisonous gas. It isn‚Äôt a dose enough to kill him, not in a single burst. But it is enough to make him lose control over his limbs and fall to the ground. 

He was too focused on Izuku to notice the attack, apparently. 

‚ÄúSo, can I dust him?‚Äù Tenko announces in the resulting silence. ‚ÄúI want the EXP.‚Äù Eraserhead looks suitably distraught and cornered. 

Izuku is happy about his best friend‚Äôs acting skills. Or, at least, he hopes that Tenko is acting. ‚ÄúOh, no need to go that far, Decay.‚Äù Izuku says. Eraserhead doesn't have time to answer. The entrance bursts open. 

‚ÄúFEAR NOT!!!‚Äù The giant announces with a voice that could shake a mountain. ‚ÄúFOR I AM HERE!!!‚Äù

Izuku bluescreens. This isn‚Äôt part of the plan. 

‚ÄúKurogiri, get Hellhound!‚Äù He shouts, his voice changer making him sound urgent but not panicked. The warpgate opens up and something massive enters the field. ‚ÄúHellhound is a bioengineered superweapon, designed to fight you at your strongest, All Might.‚Äù Izuku announces. Good bluff was a key to success. All Might doesn‚Äôt even flinch. He unleashes a flurry of blows. Hellhound is tanking them nicely, its Shock Absorption holding well. The strength behind the attack is still potent enough to push it back slightly, and each time it attempts to lunge at the Symbol of Peace with his fangs and claws, the attack is either pushed back or deflected. 

The battle is too intense for anyone to interfere. But eventually, it ends. All Might overwhelms the Shock Absorption and sends Hellhound flying through the roof. 

Izuku stares in awe, thinking that All Might is truly the coolest of heroes. Then he reminds himself that the hero just punched out Hellhound and is about to defeat the League. 

The second team picks that very moment to send him a message. A picture displays itself at the side of his vision, Mindscrew, Gentle Criminal and Gremlin making the victory signs next to several incapacitated students. 

This has to wait. 

‚ÄúSo, villains.‚Äù All Might stands up, surrounded by clouds of dust. ‚ÄúAre you going to surrender peacefully? Your ‚Äòsuperweapon‚Äô is done for, after all.‚Äù 

Is he giving them time to surrender, because he can see that most of his enemies were underage? Or‚Ä¶ 

Izuku figures it out. And screams in terror. At least internally. They are so much off the plan that they might as well have no plan at all. 

By sheer stroke of luck, that is the moment when he gets a message that the other teachers - and Thunderbolt, the Number Three Hero - are almost at the USJ. Four minutes until the second phase of the original plan can be executed. 

As Tenko would say, they were getting a continue. He just has to buy some time to make it look natural.

‚ÄúSurrender?‚Äù Izuku asks. ‚ÄúHow about this? If you manage to knock one of us out, the rest will surrender and fully cooperate with the police.‚Äù He can see the sudden sweat on All Might‚Äôs face.

‚ÄúI would prefer to not use my strength against children.‚Äù All Might is good at acting. Really good. But he doesn‚Äôt know that Legion knows about his limits. 

‚ÄúYou prefer to not use your strength‚Ä¶ or are you unable to do it?‚Äù Cornering All Might is giving him a rather complicated set of emotions. ‚ÄúNo quirk is without weaknesses.‚Äù Izuku speaks confidently. Quirks are his hobby - he loves talking about them, even in such circumstances. ‚ÄúYours is extremely powerful, and appears to be infinitely versatile. Ten seconds until the teachers arrive. He bought enough time with his villainous monologue. 

‚ÄúDecay, Vampire - kill him!‚Äù He shouts. Their attack is delayed by a further second as they are trying to comprehend why Izuku - the All Might‚Äôs number one fanboy - just told them to kill his idol. Then they decide that he has a plan, so they lunge forward. 

‚ÄúKurogiri, phase two.‚Äù He says to the living warpgate. The cloud shifts itself as it prepares for the sudden warp.

Chapter 2: USJ Aftermath
Summary:

    The UA is left to deal with the most immediate aftermath of the League's attack on the USJ, while Izuku Midoriya is left to confront his family.

Notes:

    I slightly rewrote the villain ranking system in this world. G to A-ranks are normal villains, so pretty much from the thugs to people capable of going toe to toe with ranked heroes (ranked as in numbered, not exactly top 10). Then you have supervillains, with a threat level going between S (singular 'thugs' capable of fighting Top Heroes, lesser villain organizations leaders that has managed to become infamous enough, etc.), SS (major threats, think heads of major villain/terrorist groups that can uniformly go against Top Heroes) and SSS (existential threat to the country).

    The Hosu battle comes to a rather unexpected conclusion...

Chapter 17: Villainy

    An obligatory war crime scene is here.

Chapter Text

Creature Rejection Clan was a hate group that started growing in numbers relatively recently, although it existed for a long time. It saw the mutation quirks (especially the complex ones, so Miruko‚Äôs more than Ingenium‚Äôs) as intrinsically evil and dangerous and impure yadda yadda yadda. In Izuku‚Äôs opinion you could copy paste a manifesto of any past hate group and just exchange whatever they hated with complex mutation quirks and it would summarize CRC up pretty well. 

A bit of a cruel irony, but the CRC was right from a biological point of view, at least once Purity took over. Earlier CRC hated everyone diverging from pure human form, but post-Purity they only had an issue with complex mutations. So people like Miruko, Gang Orca, Spinner or that frog girl from the USJ attack. Those mutations worked significantly differently than normal quirks (even normal mutant quirks, like Ingenium‚Äôs), typically offering a wider array of abilities. They were also absolutely dominant in terms of genetics. 

Speaking about it in a more simple terms, Miruko‚Äôs children would be rabbit people just like her. And so her grandchildren. And grand-grandchildren. Regardless of who their ‚Äòother‚Äô parents were. Complex mutant quirks typically overrode other quirks entirely when it came to inheritance. 

As a result, if Miruko and her descendants were allowed to exist, then in a few centuries there was going to be a significant group of rabbit-people living in Japan. Potentially making ‚Äòstandard‚Äô humans into merely one of subspecies of generalized Mankind. So yes - from the biological point of view, the existence of such quirks was a danger to humanity as it was understood presently.

Unfortunately for the CRC, Midoriya Izuku, League of Villains and most normal people in Japan didn‚Äôt consider having rabbit, frog, orca or lizard-people in the society as a problem. At least until they joined the mirror opposite of the CRC, the Inhuman Supremacy Party. Because, honestly, then they became assholes just like those that discriminated against them.

Stain wanted to charge in and simply slaughter everyone inside, but Izuku advised caution. Izuku turned out to be right. The small hideout of the Creature Rejection Clan was not as small as they originally suspected. 

Japan as a whole was still blissfully unaware of the exact workings of Vampire‚Äôs quirk. Stain‚Äôs interest in randomly charging and murdering people has cooled down after it, replaced with an interest in creating a plan on how to charge and murder people while being smart about it. 

‚ÄúOkay, so a quick question before we start.‚Äù Izuku announced right before they started strategizing. Everyone was gathered around the 3D model of the building printed by Gremlin and used as a map. ‚ÄúIs there anyone here who is yet to kill someone?‚Äù 

Silence. Good. They are prepared. 

‚ÄúWhy do you ask?‚Äù Mindscrew gets curious. 

‚ÄúBecause I have a very short patience when it comes to hate groups.‚Äù Izuku replies. ‚ÄúPlus we did so many semi-bloodless raids that I really think we should make it bloody for once. ‚ÄúSo‚Ä¶ we go in and kill something like one hundred fifty people?‚Äù Mustard asks for clarification. He doesn‚Äôt seem to believe in what he heard. 

‚ÄúYes.‚Äù Izuku replies calmly. Stares intensify. ‚ÄúWell, unless they manage to escape. You are free to spare those that flee.‚Äù

The CRC was a group with religious trappings. Izuku, personally, had no idea why that happened. The surface level of their base had a large hall resembling a church. Many, many pews. Candles. Stain killed too many heroes. Some of them didn‚Äôt deserve it - they should have their career‚Äôs ruined, yes, but killing was going too far. So while Izuku subscribed to the general idea that there were way too many fake heroes around, he was much less happy about Stain‚Äôs methods. 

Which is why he only tried to kill people like Endeavor and Thunderbolt, who were too powerful to be taken down non-lethally. Dabi‚Äôs revelations wouldn‚Äôt be enough to destroy the former - the HPSC would still rescue him if he survived Hosu, he was too powerful and useful to be sent to jail. The CRC fallen heroes were mostly collateral, in that Izuku didn‚Äôt consider them to be primary targets. The entire base was one big primary target. They just happened to be in the wrong place at the wrong time. 

Hearing Lemillion‚Äô analysis and the fact that Nedzu seemed to learn the lesson for now changed things even more. The idea of Legion being a hero-villain‚Ä¶ It was, somewhat, true. And if it was true, then he could as well act on it properly. With intent and will, instead of mere afterthought and unconscious wiggling. 

If spending time with Stain teached him anything, it was that you either went all-out once you decided on something or didn‚Äôt bother trying at all. His father‚Äôs inheritance was an asset that could help him achieve the goal. Why should he shy away from using it? 

‚ÄúSo you are interested in Lemillion‚Ä¶ because he is going to be your very own nemesis.‚Äù Stain says. It‚Äôs not a question, more like an observation. 

‚ÄúMore like an antithesis.‚Äù Izuku shrugs. ‚ÄúIf the collapse of my father‚Äôs empire is any indication, bad order is still better than chaos. He was a monster, but he kept things ordered. All Might is his polar opposite who tried to achieve the same thing. Symbol of Peace to oppose the Symbol of Evil. He knows that people need symbols. This is why the heroes honest to the word gathered around him and around the UA. And why the fakes all crowded around the Hero Commission and its president, the unofficial Symbol of Corruption. When ideologies are in conflict, the people develop convictions and dedication to their causes. And this is my plan.‚Äù

Stain understands. And laughs. There is pride and interest in his laughter. 

‚ÄúSo you will dismantle the Hero Commission to get rid of fake heroes.‚Äù He says with his eyes gleaming. ‚ÄúMaking those worthy of the title band around the new Symbol of Peace. All of that while dismantling the current villain groups, too dangerous and uncontrollable to continue existing. And when they are gone‚Ä¶ your name will become the rallying cry of the remaining villains. The ones that you will allow to exist.‚Äù 

‚ÄúAnd thus I will become the new Symbol of Evil.‚Äù Izuku smiles. ‚ÄúThe polar opposite to Lemillion and whoever the next holder of the One for All will be. When the society will be working as it should, my resources will be limited and the Symbol of Peace will be triumphing. When peace and prosperity begin to wane, leaving people downtrodden and seeking a different world, I‚Äôll be there to guide them‚Ä¶ and force the country to change. Or change it myself. I will create a world where heroes are heroes and villains are villains. Where fakes will be an exception and not a rule.‚Äù Izuku smiles at his uncle. ‚ÄúSo will you become my blade, Uncle Stain?‚Äù 

Stain stares at him for a few seconds. Izuku doesn‚Äôt feel intimidated. Not anymore. And finally, the Hero Killer speaks.

‚ÄúWhen I heard you talk about your ideals for the first time after we met again, I actually considered slaughtering the League. You included. ‚ÄúStain says, genuinely surprising Izuku. ‚ÄúYou talked a lot, and there was a clear dedication to your ideas‚Ä¶ but what about that? I could feel how immature you were deep enough. You were incredibly smart, reasonably ruthless and had resources - the soil was perfect, yet what grew in it was mismatched. Almost‚Ä¶ fake.‚Äù 

Izuku didn‚Äôt expect Stain to describe him in such words. It was a lethal thing for most people. But Stain didn‚Äôt stop talking.

‚ÄùYou considered yourself to have the ironclad determination and goal, but something was missing in both.‚Äù The Hero Killer continues. ‚ÄúSome crucial element. But you were and are young, so I decided to give you a chance. So I tagged along, to see what was going to sprout from the seed that I saw in you. You took down Endeavor, and massacred the Clan‚Ä¶ both great moves, but in both I saw you lacking. There was strength and smarts there, but you didn‚Äôt seem to know where you were heading to. You showed me a mess of disjointed lines where you promised a drawing, random acts instead of a clear strategy to achieve your goals. You, perhaps unconsciously, were trying to find an answer for yourself.‚Äù

Stain pauses for a few seconds. Part of Izuku expects his sword to suddenly behead him. But this doesn‚Äôt happen. 

‚ÄúMy decision to wait was the correct one, it seems.‚Äù Stain smiles. His smile is in equal part terrifying and reassuring. ‚ÄúThe seed finally sprouted. You finally see the big picture. You finally have a true goal in your life. One that you will follow until you die‚Ä¶ or until you reach it. Your eyes are no longer clouded with indecisiveness when you talk about your father‚Äôs heritage and about your own villainous career. I see no indecisiveness in you at all. And because of that‚Ä¶‚Äù Their eyes meet. ‚Äú... the answer is yes. I‚Äôll be your blade, because you are finally worthy of wielding me. Let‚Äôs murder Eclipse together.‚Äù

Chapter 20: Resurrection
Summary:

    Plot earthquake incoming. But first, some fluff.

    Also FIVE HUNDRED KUDOS, damn. Things are going pretty nice. STILL PLEASE NOTICE THAT I HAVE TWO MORE STORIES HERE AND THEY NEED SOME LOVE TOO :V

Notes:

    ALRIGHT I WAS REPEATEDLY ASKED ABOUT ECLIPSE QUIRK SO IT'S TIME TO EXPLAIN IT TO YOU. Because it kinda doesn't happen (at least in detail) in the story.

    https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=HZlHD0v_J_Q I was initially inspired to create when I saw this music piece, or to be exact, the accompanying image. You see that floaty black-with-yellow-edges bit behind her? Eclipse can generate and control multiple similar surfaces, which carry the properties of any surface she wants to from her vicinity. Of about 25cm of said surface. If she is walking on concrete floor, she can generate floating disks, each of which is an equivalent of 25cm of concrete.

    Also fun fact - those are just surface. There are two-dimensional. This makes their edges into monomolecular blades capable of slicing through practically everything. Yes, it would go through All Might like a hot knife through butter. And then she had a quirk awakening and figured out how to give her surface properties of an area of space (say, air) from different place altogether, essentially creating a warpgate between her current position and said place.

    This is why late-bloomers are so feared in-universe. Her quirk showing up elevated her from small-time quirkless terrorist into a nightmare that will murder (instantly or almost instantly) most heroes out there. In 1vs 1 the only heroes that can win against her are Hawks (her quirk offers her a lot of defenses, but it's not omnidirectional and his feathers might find their target between the surface shields), Thunderbolt (if she is on the ground, he could knock her out instantly before giving her time to realize that an attack is incoming), Endeavor (unless she drags him somewhere where there are some highly fire-resistant surfaces to operate, he would probably win through brute force and melting through her surfaces), and All Might (strong enough to shatter her shields, quick enough to avoid getting cut in half, at least probably).

    There is a reason why the whole League is ambushing her at once, 'ya know.

The operation started as it should. Then it immediately derailed into complete chaos. 

Eclipse had a bit above nine hundred soldiers and twenty-three tanks (plus two self-propelled missile launchers armed with the gas) on standby in the base. High morale, people were really heated up by the string of victories and a single tie (she is going to skin Miruko and Gang Orca at some point in the future for that). The idea of attacking Musutafu was met with an ovation. 

She used her quirk to summon a surface and connect it to the Musutafu‚Äôs main square, right next to the local governmental office. She stepped through it (she can only teleport herself or summon others to her), noticing something was strange with it but not to a point where the warping failed. Like always, she makes herself float atop one of her surfaces, nothing is more attention-grabbing than floating menacingly above the crowd you are about to slaughter.

 And then the plan dies. Screaming. 

She expects a bunch of civilians minding their own business (and immediately going into a total panic once they see her) and probably several local heroes. They would attack her immediately, hoping to delay the gas and give the civilians time to flee, but‚Ä¶ Kamui Woods, Mt. Lady and Death Arms aren‚Äôt actually that powerful. She could deal with all three at once. In a manner of seconds.

And that‚Äôs without counting the army that would join her in a minute.

Instead she sees the last civilians fleeing from the square, an absolute lack of heroes around‚Ä¶ and several figures that she recognizes as members of the League of Villains scattered in front of her. 

Then she finds out that she can‚Äôt open a gate for her soldiers to pour in. 

‚ÄúMy name is Legion and we are the League of Villains.‚Äù The figure in the All Might hoodie standing behind the crowd, right next to the League‚Äôs warpgate, announces. ‚ÄúWe‚Äôve decided to interrupt your assault on Musutafu in order to punish you for stealing our kill. And end your irritating rampage.‚Äù Legion sighs and adds in a different voice. ‚ÄúDestroying cities is bad for business, you see.‚Äù 

Of course the kid was pissed off by it. Chronostasis was right - Legion IS a revenge-freak. And she just, as he said, ‚Äòmade it personal‚Äô. She should have listened to her second-in-command a bit more. 

Oh well. She just has to kill them all and find whatever machine or a person is deactivating her warp. Then she can resume her attack on the town.

‚ÄúI heard that you were a late-bloomer.‚Äù She says confidently. She knows her skills. She battled many pro-heroes. She only took down Endeavor in his depowered state because of the delicious irony - the flame hero flaunted the strength of his quirk, so she slew him in front of millions in a state of de-facto quirklessness. She was confident she was at least his equal. And he would massacre the League if Stain didn‚Äôt catch him off-guard. ‚ÄúShouldn‚Äôt you be at least somewhat amenable to the Front‚Äôs goals?‚Äù She uses the time to scan the area. 

Perhaps the heroes will arrive, turning this into a melee-a-trois. Legion is a good planner, she knows that well enough. Chronostasis AND recent League‚Äôs actions are a good proof of that. If she buys enough time for the heroes to arrive, she can take advantage of chaos. 

She sees nothing that could be a warp suppression machine. But she also doesn‚Äôt see their engineer. Suspicious. 

‚ÄúOh, but I am amenable to your goals!‚Äù Legion says with a cheerful voice. ‚ÄúJust not to your methods. Do you have the tiniest idea how many quirkless kids has their bullying intensify each time you commit a mass-murder? Then again, that‚Äôs probably a feature, not a bug. I mean, the more they are bullied, the more likely they are to join the Front. Am I right?‚Äù 

Did he just suggest that‚Ä¶ Eclipse is beyond furious. She is going to murder every single League member. Brutally. Perhaps she will take some alive and have them tortured. She spent two decades fighting a war against people treating quirkless as subhumans, and she isn‚Äôt taking words like that face down. 

‚ÄúYou sh‚Ä¶‚Äù Suddenly, she freezes. Quirk. Mental. Is it Mindscrew‚Äôs? She can see him, standing before Legion with a rifle. Eye contact?

‚Äú Remain stationary for the next ten seconds. ‚Äù She hears his voice. Stain throws knives at her, Mindscrew pulls up his rifle. She didn‚Äôt survive her childhood as a quirkless without a willpower of steel. She promptly shatters the quirk. Surfaces (round and black with yellow edges, she made it look like that to fit her villain name) block the attacks. 

She isn‚Äôt going to get caught like that again. 

‚ÄúThis is cheating.‚Äù She hears someone, probably Mindscrew, say. ‚ÄúHow did you do that?‚Äù She is about to respond with a taunt, when suddenly she has a breakthrough.

She stands there, on a floating surface, summoning several more. Her limit is fifteen, but when she gets close to it, she has problems overseeing all of them at once. She flings two at Legion, but he dodges - her control is so-so at a distance, too, so she fails to make the surfaces follow him. 

They are two-dimensional. You can stand on them, or connect two (even distant) surfaces, but their edges slice through all matter. They are essentially monomolecular circular saw-blades. Her quirk is powerful, like it‚Äôs common for the late bloomers.

One of the nearest League members suddenly triples in size and lunges at her. She reacts instantly. She fought Re-Destro once and managed to bring it to a tie, she knows how to deal with strength enhancers. She reacts in time and stops the punch with four surfaces arrayed one after another.

That‚Äôs a dangerous level of strength. That villain (she faintly remembers him, what was the name, Zealot?) has strength approaching Re-Destro‚Äôs. ‚ÄúYou are a life-saver, Unclegiri.‚Äù Kurogiri reacts in no discernible way to yet another butchering of his villain name. ‚ÄúSo, you wanted something from me?‚Äù He says while stuffing himself with sandwiches. Waving is a bit unlike their warper.

If the trainees will be good enough, then the entire ‚ÄòVillain Academy‚Äô can finance itself by selling their skills in exchange for practical experience as a form of internships. And the graduates can pay back the remaining cash in installments from their villain career. 

Besides, even if graduates get captured by the heroes, the League can survive losing some money if it means a higher level of professional villainy out there! Not to mention that many active villains will simply pay the Academy to train their kids for them. 

‚ÄúThis is beautiful, Kurogiri!‚Äù Izuku beams up, and he can feel the happiness radiating from the warper. ‚ÄúI name you the first principal of the Villain Academy!‚Äù It‚Äôs like the Villain Factory but this time less retarded. ‚ÄúAnd offer you the League‚Äôs full support!‚Äù

Izuku should go spend some time with his family today.

Notes:

    Well, All Might's party in the US and Nana being pissed off at him for it is a bit of a running gag throughout the entire series. I'm never saying what it was, leaving that for readers' headcanon. Just like whatever Mei's planned present for Izuku was.

    Also this chapter is both Izuku Midoriya finding a refuge in audacity (knowing full well that he can't hide himself using All for One-the-quirk for long, nor his attempts to rebuild his father's legacy from Mirio Togata, so the only way of delaying the inevitable for reasonable amount of time is either significantly confusing or persuading Lemillion that Izuku is doing all of that in good will) and slightly losing his calm.

    He idolizes All Might, but unlike the canon, he never gets into any significant contact with All Might (save for brief incidents like the USJ). Instead, Lemillion kind of takes the cake of being... well, not a father figure, the age difference is too small, but certainly an idol to a degree. So he deep inside wants to impress him/make him like him, however childish it might be considering the whole 'archvillain in training' status.

    Then again, it's the same kid that in canon 'hides One for All' despite yelling its name in most of his techniques because he finally has a goddamn quirk and this is something that he finds hard to keep in. Yeah.

    Of course, his attempt to bamboozle Lemillion by telling him the truth is going to be rendered a bit redundant by another plottwist in the story that's coming in two chapters ahead of this one. Anyone has any guesses as for what that's going to be? :P

***

ISP was using a large tea plantation as a cover. The building had a surprisingly expansive underground section serving as barracks, and it was right next to a large forested area used by the local ISP cell as a training area. Mostly at night - there was no one around the plantation to notice an awkward number of complex mutant quirk users emerging from it right after the sunset. 

The police were yet to find an explanation for some missing campers and hunters in the area. Sure, only four during the last two years. But the forest was still slowly developing a reputation. And not a good one. 

He had Spinner observe the camp for three days. He found about seventy members of the ISP in the area, including five B or C-Ranks (rest was D or E). 

Izuku chuckled menacingly when he found out. It was time to practise operations in forested areas. And he had just a perfect idea in mind for it.

Chapter 29: Training Camp [Part One]

Chapter Text

Zealot is reasonably angry. And lost. Mostly lost. His spatial awareness is‚Ä¶ lacking, to say the least. He has no idea where he is, and he has no idea which direction is which. He is too lost to be able to focus on his anger.

And he has a lot of it. 

His life is, objectively speaking, a mess. Being born to a supervillain is bad enough. He can‚Äôt express with words alone how much he relates with Midoriya Izuku. Only his supervillain parent was charismatic enough to make him do some extremely bad things before he changed his mind. 

The change happened mostly due to him reading about the religious sources of the CRC. He had no idea how much of the CRC teachings were just petty hatred coated in words of people who would have wanted nothing to do with clan members. Although this is perhaps a wrong thing to say - most of those people would have wanted Purity dead or jailed. They were mostly against inactivity in the face of evil.

So he threw out everything that felt like re-packaged hatred, turned towards some actually constructive teachings of long dead people. But he still felt guilt. He couldn‚Äôt become a hero, but he could be a vigilante. 

How exactly he became a villain was a mystery to him. But it wasn‚Äôt a bad type of a villain, all things considered. So he could still use his quirk. He still remembers how it basically died out on him when he realized that he was doing evil things to undeserving people as a part of the CRC. Persuading himself that he is worthy of his own power took him a while. 

He still could power up to Gear Five (his maximum) only when facing people like Purge. People whose evil he knew and understood personally. People whom he couldn‚Äôt see as anything other than monsters. Monsters seeking to harm the innocents for their own petty gain. 

Only Gear Four otherwise, and even this took a lot of effort. Like facing the polar opposite of his old ‚Äòfamily‚Äô, the ISP. 

Overhaul sounded like someone to beat that record. Zealot barely restrained his desire for murder when boss narrated to him and the remaining old followers of Stain what Overhaul did to his sister. 

But no Overhaul in sight. Eventually he did run into someone, but those certainly weren‚Äôt people warranting the attention of his quirk. 

Students. He didn‚Äôt recognize what course they were from. Seven people, three of them badly wounded and carried by their friends. They were running away from something, judging from some of them glancing behind them. But then they froze when they saw him emerge from the woods in front of him. 

‚ÄúWh‚Ä¶ who are you?‚Äù One of the students asks. Ironically enough, a complex mutant quirk carrier. A kin of the people he once killed for the CRC. Some mammalian creature.

One of her other friends screams - the abominations began to emerge from the woods behind them.  

‚ÄúKeep running.‚Äù He says and starts walking towards them. ‚ÄúDon‚Äôt look back.‚Äù 

They do as he say. 

Gear Four. 

He feels his body grow, the addictive feeling of power and fury overwhelming his every limb. How many people - kids, maybe not a lot younger than him, but still kids - did they kill? How many did they wound? How many of their victims were here because they wanted to help others? To be heroes? 

Gear Five. 

He closes the distance and punches the nearest noumu through its abdomen. It flies back, screeching and howling like Zealot would imagine a demon would. 

He destroys the monsters left and right, but they just keep coming. Is that their main force? Is he going to die here? No help in sight. Just enemies. Crawling, walking, running and flying towards him. He can feel his arms tire, he can feel his skin getting cut and bruised. Gear Five doesn‚Äôt make him invincible, not against those many enemies, not for so long.  

Is he going to die? Just like that? To be remembered as a villain that fell in battle against other villains?

But‚Ä¶ will it be that bad if the kids get to safety? Will it be that bad to die if his last act will be saving a kin of those he once killed? Wouldn‚Äôt it be great to at least die like a hero should?

Gear Six.

Zealot kills ninety-four Noumus - including four High Ends - before getting overwhelmed by their numbers. His last stand buys the students gathering at the training field in the middle of the camp fifteen minutes. 

He dies happy.

Notes:

    Let's go chronologically through that, alright?

    1. Zealot's Gear Five made him reach 40-50% of All Might's strength. Here he discovered that he could go further (feel free to guess how many percent it gave him), only when he understood that he wasn't going to survive that battle yet still stood his ground to save people. An act so manly (and rather unexpected, the idea for this scene came to me like two chapters ago) that it made his every alternative version in every alternative installment of the series realize their wish of (eventually, sometimes it takes them a while to get there) becoming pro heroes.

    [and just so we're clear, his quirk is incredibly powerful but, also, balanced. He can't do shit to ambushes, and if he didn't hear about you committing heinous crimes, he can only employ a fraction of his strength. What's more, that's a transformative quirk, so unlike One for All normally (so not in damaged All Might's body), he can maintain his powered-up state only for some time, his 15-minute last stand was probably him reaching his time limit or getting pretty close to it. What's more, he lacks One for All's resistance to 'death touch' quirks (although this is something that'll be explored much later)]

    2. I don't like Magne. Like, seriously. Her literally only appeal to the masses is that she is transsexual, she doesn't have enough screentime to gain popularity any other way. Her first appearance in canon has her beat up a bunch of kids and their teacher, which she is clearly enjoying. Hell, one of these teachers is transsexual (Tiger). And guess what? Despite his borderline cross-dressing hero outfit, despite being a part of a hero team (something that's apparently not very popular in-universe), he managed to become (well, as a group) Number 32 hero. More than that, he is teaching a bunch of children on a semi-regular basis and absolutely no one bats an eye on that. Yet somehow Magne is often glorified in fanfics, while Tiger is completely ignored.

    So sorry. The transsexuals are clearly accepted in canon Japan. Magne and her unnamed friend's problem isn't their transsexuality, it's the fact that they are violent thugs. #TeamTiger here, people. Especially as considering the possibility that quirks affect their holders' personality, she might not even have gender dysphoria and instead have a defect in her gender-oriented quirk.

    Muscular and Moonfish also had some rather bad match-up quirkwise against Stain. The former because he is a brawler who is casual with getting hit and there are blood vessels in muscles, the latter because his teeth-blades aren't precise enough to stop small projectiles. Hence, Stain bulldozing through all three of them, while shocked heroes are staring. Although whether their participation in the plot is truly over remains to be seen.

    3. Gremlin is a complicated case. In at least one not really written (okay, 13 chapters but they are going to be rewritten grounds up, also it's All That's Left) fanfic connected to this she has an undiagnosed Class-Six quirk practically flooding her brain with engineering and scientific ideas whenever she wants to construct something (while also making her slightly unstable and prone to having to finish constructing said something to clear her mind properly and allow her to function), with her eyes being actually cybernetic implant made to conceal that fact by pretending to be her quirk.

    Whether it's like this here (I mean, Izuku has no real reason to use All for One-the-quirk to inspect one of his friends) is anyone's guess. I'm leaving that to your headcanons.

    Still, you finally get to witness one of her dreaded episodes.

    Cure to Evil Mei: Geneva Convention? More like Geneva Suggestion.
    Cure to Evil Mei [during the episode]: *looks through the list of Geneva Convention bans for inspiration*

Notes:

    I'm seriously considering switching to weekly releases for all of my stories... as much as we all love having daily or semi-daily releases, let's be real. It means much less time for my story to amass comments and kudos before I end up finishing it ;_; People comment much less on finished works, after all. Not to mention being able to amass more backlog and so on.

    And for as much as I hate that fact, my writing IS kind of fueled by me receiving attention from people. Low self-esteem does that to people. Sigh. I was quite happy about getting to 1000 kudos, then quite sad because my two other stories from the series (that I GREATLY recommend) are only about 300 kudos each, then I realized how many kudos actually popular stories have, and ... yeah, here we are.

    Dead on Arrival got an unexpected follow/favourite on FF from one of my favourite authors on FF yesterday, which kind of stopped me from spiraling into a bad place, still. Not a nice evening to have.

    Still need to spend a day thinking about it. Tomorrow's releases of all three stories will be probably accompanied by announcement (or not). Sorry for that, in advance, if it happens, but... well, I kind of want this story to be as successful as possible, you catch my drift?

Notes:

    1. Rabbit's quirk was designed BEFORE Star and Stripe showed up in canon. Yes, I know it's a bit similar. The difference is that Total Command's limited to status condition, but on the other hand, you could technically boost a two digit number of people with some empowering statuses (think Powerful to boost your quirk and physical strength up or, if you go against people like Endeavor, Fireproof etc.). It also has a small degree of 'reality warping' included, as why it's not mentioned here (but probably will be in Answering the Call once I write it), giving someone a 'Free' status condition undoes not only mind control quirks but also physical bindings.

    2. It's not fully developed due to being awoken in a life-threatening situation, slightly ahead of schedule (as stated in the last chapter). Rabbit's quirk in other stories from that series are significantly stronger, allowing him to put his status conditions onto himself, or being permanent (although permanent until the connection last, so 24h unless touched again in that period to reset the counter, and not with some of the strongest status conditions like Imperceptible or Invincible, which still have a timer). Healthy still works best on diseases and scratches though, it's not Rewind.

    3. Ngl, Izuku and All for One geeking about the quirk together sort of warms my heart. Before I remember how many people the latter killed to obtain their cool quirks. Then it... starts being a bit questionable.

    4. Contrary to popular opinions, Total Command isn't a reference to That One Fic, because I dropped it rather quickly for a multitude of reasons. And I don't understand the hype.

Well, that was the last thing Izuku wanted to talk about.

List of Major Villainous Organizations

 

Threat Rank: SSS

Paranormal Liberation Front: Revolutionary group from the merger of the Quirkless Liberation Front with a number of other factions, including a previously unknown scientific genius Doctor Garaki and his menagerie of noumus. Its stated goal is overthrowing the hero society - and the society as a whole - in order to ‚Äòliberate‚Äô what‚Äôs considered abnormal by it. Suffered heavy casualties during the several large-scale raids by the heroes during the last two months.

 

Meta-Liberation Army: Revolutionary group led by Re-Destro, who preaches the ideals of freeing the society from the restrictions on the quirk usage, allowing anyone to use them at their convenience. Quirk-supremacists, preaching that the strength of your quirk dictates your value and importance to the society at large. Its state as a de facto regular army of the Free Republic of Japan (on Hokkaido) equals large numbers and possibility of open military exercises. 

 

League of Villains: Part-criminal syndicate part-revolutionary group. According to its manifest, it seeks a world where heroes and villains unworthy of their names are gone. Majority of its powers lie in numerous subsidiary groups, especially the smaller ones (while many high profile groups joined the PLF, the overwhelming majority of smaller villain organizations joined the League). 

 

Threat Rank: SS

Levellers : A troupe of ‚Äònoble thieves‚Äô, claiming to be led by a direct descendant of the Peerless Thief. Staged dozens of high-profile heists against companies indicted of malfeasance and heroes that its members found unheroic. Actual numbers unknown. Currently allied with the League of Villains. 

 

Creature Rejection Clan : An anti-complex quirk terrorist organization, responsible for numerous riots, pogroms and assassinations of complex quirk rights activists. Suffered heavy casualties during a hero raid (and League of Villains‚Äô attack). Pending reclassification to Rank S organization. Currently allied with the Paranormal Liberation Front.

 

Inhuman Supremacy Party : A pro-complex quirk terrorist organization, responsible for numerous riots, massacres and other attacks. Despite years of fighting against each other with extreme ferocity, it has recently joined the PLF alongside the Creature Rejection Clan. 

 

Villain Industries : An underground corporation producing weapons, tools and support equipment for villains throughout the country. Emerged relatively recently, however its logo is now a symbol of highest quality (and becomes more and more common-place). Currently allied with the League of Villains.

 

Threat Rank: S

Quirkless Equality Movement : Quirkless terror group that has replaced the Quirkless Liberation Front following its merger into the Paranormal Liberation Front. Expanded rapidly, and is steadily becoming more and more active (with steadily rising number of terror attacks attributed to it). Currently allied with the League of Villains.

 

Exchange: Independent information brokership and espionage organization, which also acts as an intermediary for numerous other illegal deals. Responsible for numerous cases of industrial espionage, hacking attempts and no less than seventeen assassinations during the past two months alone. Currently allied with the League of Villains.

 

House of Red : Organization of serial killers and wanna-be mass murderers, whose members typically possess powerful quirks and a taste in blood. Its existence was an urban legend for decades, but its existence was confirmed only recently. Currently allied with the Paranormal Liberation Front.

‚ÄúMera.‚Äù She says into the phone once the man on the other end picks it up. ‚ÄúDeploy the Paragons. Now.‚Äù

Snatch was a hero that specialized in convoy escort. He was the man who was tasked with making sure that the dangerous villains stopped by the other heroes made it safely to the prisons. 

His quirk had nothing to do with speed. It was sand control. But he had a lot of it stored in his car. It made his car go with only a moderate speed, but allowed him to field significant firepower when his convoy was attacked.

Chapter 52: Coup [II]
Summary:

    Things no longer go accordingly to the plan. Accordingly to anyone's plan, to be honest.

Notes:

    In my defense, I know this is a low blow. Like the whole 'make the world think for like one chapter that Hagakure is a traitor before revealing that NOPE' that Horikoshi pulled. I should... left some suggestions that things were going to go in a bit different in the last chapter, something more pronounced than 'Mera, deploy the Paragons'. Sorry for that.

(See the end of the chapter for more notes.)
Chapter Text

Up until that very moment, the coup was progressing according to plan‚Ä¶ and actually ahead of schedule. The only serious delays were the Gang Orca‚Äôs assault on the HPSC headquarters occurred almost an hour late due to a completely unexpected traffic jam, and Hound Dog‚Äôs assault on the Sweet Dreams Agency. 

After less than five hours of fighting, the majority of the notable Hero Commission-aligned hero agencies have either fallen, or were busy falling to the attacks. The only Top 15 Heroes serving the Commission that were yet to be incarcerated were those that were currently serving as a part of the Northern Battle Group (so Yoroi Muusha and Boulder, and only the former was willing to bleed for the Commission) and Dreamer. 

Hawks was dead. Scream and Snatch were arrested. Almost all notable independent hero agencies refused to side with the HPSC (although typically they chose neutrality). The police took the neutral option as well, save for its Commissioner General. The JSDF were entirely forgotten in the chaos, and its soldiers were watching the chaos in the media. Besides, it would take it further hours to deploy, even if the president remembered that it exists. 

Most of all, Gang Orca took over 75% of the HPSC headquarters, with the remaining heroes and security units in the building unlikely to offer significant resistance. In fact, the resistance was almost entirely broken at this point, with the remaining defenders typically choosing to surrender at the first sight of Gang Orca‚Äôs sidekicks. 

It appeared that the coup succeeded. Unfortunately, the situation was a bit more complicated than that.

‚ÄúSNIPER, GET DOWN!‚Äù one of the Paragons that arrived on the helicopter shouted. The president felt her bodyguards throwing her on the ground. A second later she heard the thunderous sound and what felt like a nearby explosion.

Whoever was there either died or fled, for there was no fourth shot.

Paragon? Gang Orca‚Äôs thoughts drift to what they knew about Hawks‚Äô past. How the Commission pretty much bought him from his family and then trained him in secret for years before showing him to the world.

That bitch prepared her own private army in secret?

Marvellous.

Chapter 53: Tartarus
Summary:

    PLF's attacks on the Tartarus Prison. The heroes and the League scramble to respond. The result is most unexpected.

Notes:

    TWO THOUSAND KUDOS PEOPLE!!! You know the rules and so do I. IT'S BONUS RELEASE TIME! Most likely the last one in the history of this fic, because we all know that we won't make it to 3000 kudos before the conclusion.

Chapter Text

Tartarus is a special place. There is no other location like that in the world - there are many inescapable prisons for the worst of the worst (or, in some unfortunate countries, for the best of the best), but there is just a single Tartarus. 

The bulk of the facility is located one kilometer off the coast of Japan. Only the uppermost layer extends over the waters - the remaining three are under it or, in case of the third one, are located under the bottom of the sea. 

The surface layer is the biggest one. It houses close to seven thousand A-Rank villains (and some choice B-Ranks whose crimes were sufficiently terrible). It has several blocks concentrated around the central spire, which is a fortress within a fortress - its twenty meters tall walls made from the hardest materials that Japan had access to house the command center of the entire prison, barracks for the wardens, on-site hospital, and enough weapons and combat robots to wage and win a small war. 

It‚Äôs not often, but sometimes one of the inmates from this level gets to leave the prison. Save for a single block (the one for the most insane and deadly of the A-Rankers), the uppermost layer is a simple, if high security, prison. There are quirk suppressors and ever watchful wardens, but the inmates get to stretch their legs a bit. 

There are no such privileges for those housed in the segments hidden under the surface - save for some choice exceptions, typically brought by extremely good behaviour and some attenuating circumstances. The first underwater segment houses one thousand seventy-four S-Rank villains, including a bit more than a hundred of those from Japan. 

The United States, Korea, the Siberian Federation and even the European Alliance (to a smaller degree) all contributed to the number - Tartarus is the world‚Äôs highest security prison, and Japan bought a lot of political favors by taking in inmates from the other countries. 

Beneath that level lies the second underwater segment, this time housing two-hundred twenty-four SS-Rank villains, with twenty-two from that number being Japanese. Villains of this rank are typically executed after capture (just like majority of S-Ranks), but there are some for whom execution is seen as a form of mercy they do not deserve. And some who are seen as not deserving death for exactly opposite reasons - their accomodation on this level varies greatly, but not the security tightness around their cells. 

Situation of the seventy-two SSS-Rank villains housed in the underground level of Tartarus is similar. Although only twelve of those are Japanese, almost uniformly former All for One‚Äôs lieutenants captured by the All Might during his long war against his fated nemesis. 

The entire facility is defended by two thousand wardens, seventy-five heroes stationed there permanently and numerous combat robots and automatic security measures. Wardens and heroes alike come from multiple countries, and have their past screened with extreme attention to details. Even the slightest sign of past misbehaviour is enough for the Head Warden to refuse an application. 

But that‚Äôs merely a single part of the Tartarus defenses. The waters surrounding are permanently patrolled by a detachment of the Japan Maritime Self-Defense Force. Sonars constantly scan the underwater for any signs of an attack. Ships themselves are armed to the teeth (with both conventional weaponry and water-oriented heroes) and only give the approaching ships a single warning before annihilating them if they do not change their course. 

The only alternative way of accessing the prison are two kilometre-long bridges connecting the facility with the mainland. However, there is another layer of defense there. An escapee that would manage to cross the bridge would have found himself in the middle of the last remaining base of the ground forces of the JSDF. Surrounded by ten thousand soldiers, armed with the best of the conventional weaponry that was created before quirks made those obsolete.

And it‚Äôs not like it was just a ‚Äònormal‚Äô military base, as it would be understood by someone from a centuries past. Like Tartarus itself, the entire base was a labyrinth of concrete and steel, overseen by the automatic gun turrets and artillery towers. Less a base and more a massive and interconnected network of bunkers, designed to force the enemy forces to divide itself between core bastions, and then whittle their numbers in numerous killing fields. 

Tartarus was designed to withstand every imaginable assault. Unfortunately, the one that Overhaul organized was anything but imaginable. 

 

***

The first thing that happened was the technopathic attack. This time performed not by a single trigger-boosted quirk bearer - but by twenty trigger-boosted quirk bearers. The Tartarus‚Äô security was naturally improved after the Training Camp battle, but not to this degree. 

Throughout the facility the security gates opened up, automatic turrets went highwire and opened fire on the allies, artillery turrets exploded due to induced mishandling of its ammo stockpiles, the communication networks died down, robots began to rampage and hundreds of cells stood wide open, unleashing the monsters imprisoned inside.

Not all of them had their quirk suppressor disabled, and even then the overwhelming majority of the escapees were from the A-Rank block. But it still occupied the attention of the wardens. Just as PLFs‚Äô main forces emerged from the forest surrounding the JSDF base. Artillery rounds began to rain on it, just as dozens of tanks (some made according to designs that predated the birth of quirks) rolled towards the concrete walls of the fortress, accompanied by the noumus. 

Turrets and towers that survived the technopathic attack returned fire. Ships in the distance began to launch sea-to-ground missiles. The battle started.

Tanks and noumus were a good distraction. Defenders of the outer walls of Tartarus didn‚Äôt notice Overhaul himself and a hundred of his Purified marching behind the first line of attack until it was too late. 

 

***

Nedzu didn‚Äôt expect to have his day interrupted by a phone call. Especially not from the president of the HPSC. And even more especially not right now, when he was busy trying to clean up after the unfortunately failed coup. 

He entertained the idea of not answering it. His day was already pretty bad at this point. Sure, throwing expletives at that witch would be enjoyable, but having to hear her voice‚Ä¶ Was it really worth it? 

He was way too busy trying to find a way to protect people like Tsuyu Asui from going to jail for doing the right thing. Due to the very person that was now calling him. 

In the end, he picks it up. He isn‚Äôt sure why. 

‚ÄúWhat is it, you‚Ä¶‚Äù He chirps in, only to be brutally interrupted.

‚ÄúOVERHAUL IS ATTACKING VILLAIN PRISONS EVERYWHERE!‚Äù The president shouts at him, in an obvious panic. Nedzu freezes even before his mind computes the words. The tone itself, it‚Äôs something he never heard. It‚Äôs something he never expects her to use in public, and especially when contacting her archenemy. ‚ÄúINCLUDING TARTARUS! SEND EVERYONE YOU HAVE, NOW!‚Äù 

Oh dear.

Principal: EMERGENCY SORTIE

Principal: OVERHAUL IS ATTACKING NO LESS THAN FIFTEEN HIGH SECURITY PRISONS THROUGHOUT JAPAN

Principal: INCLUDING TARTARUS

 

Well, shit. 

Izuku‚Äôs panic reaches new heights when they gather up only to discover that the nearest place where Kurogiri can drop anyone is fifteen kilometers away from Tartarus.

Kai Yoshiyuki is a relic.

His soldiers did their best. This wasn‚Äôt enough. And the support fire from the ships was growing thin, as they were sunk or forced to retreat by the enemy artillery. 

The battle is hopeless. But he still has a duty to uphold. And a history to end in a way that will make him feel ashamed to stand in front of his ancestors and predecessors.

He contacts his best friend - the head warden of Tartarus - and tells him that he will buy him as much time as possible. Then he says his last words to his soldiers through whatever remains of the base communication network, and gathers his command unit, before leading it into combat. 

The 1st Division of the Japanese Ground Self Defense Force stops existing as an organized fighting force ten minutes later. Out of 10 000 soldiers that participated in the battle, close to half died while the rest were either overlooked by the enemy or managed to escape.

Takano Ryuu, the head warden of Tartarus, has no time to grieve. He knows that help is coming. He knows that All Might is battling it out there, but he sees the army storming the facility. Army that stands between the prison and the rescue force. 

All Might is powerful. Indomitable. But he is alone, or with only a handful of other heroes. They will not get to Tartarus in time. The technopathic attack has already deactivated Tartarus‚Äô warp scramblers. The enemy can simply warp the rescued prisoners from the prison. 

The only warp scramblers left are those of the PLF. And they are set to not interfere with their warpers. 

Thousands of quirkless soldiers in exchange for thousands of high-ranking criminals? He would make that trade, if he was Overhaul. The PLF will use their main forces to distract the relief force long enough, even if it will have to send them out as suicide bombers. 

Takano Ryuu wishes that he had other options. But he has none. Not today. Not when the heroes throughout the country just bled themselves almost dry.

The Northern Battle Group had its headquarters near the place where the Aomori, Iwate and Akita prefectures met. It was permanently garrisoned by Yoroi Muusha, no less than three additional Top 15 Heroes, about two hundred unranked heroes (like those from Tartarus, they said goodbye to popularity and fame and instead opted to serve in de-facto military), one thousand soldiers of the Ground Self-Defense Force and similar number of policemen from the riot units. 

The HPSC couldn‚Äôt predict where exactly the MLA would land, hence the positioning. Those three prefectures - due to being the northernmost ones - were the most likely targets for the invasion if Re-Destro decided to invade Japan. If the attack occurred, local heroes and police units were supposed to delay it, giving the NBG time to sortie with full force and push the attackers back into the sea. 

It was, in full honesty, a fool-proof strategy. The one hundred thousand warriors of the MLA had some heavy-hitters, but the majority of them were a mob. It was the joint estimation of the UA and the HPSC that a single unranked hero was an equivalent of twenty to thirty regular MLA warriors. Riot units of the Japanese Police and the JGSDF were capable of eliminating MLA units several times their size as well. 

Unfortunately, the situation changed when the MLA executives came into play. People like Trumpet or Skeptic were capable of going toe-to-toe with Top 30 Heroes. Slidin‚ÄôGo excelled in a single combat, and played in similar league to people like Mr. Compress or Stain. Geten was a living weapon of mass destruction, a man capable of freezing a small city with a flick of his finger and an overbearing desire to show his power to the world.  

And then, there was Re-Destro. Man whose stress made him stronger. Man who fought Endeavor and Thunderbolt at once during his coup and emerged victorious, the coup failing only because All Might arrived at the scene and stopped Re-Destro from capturing the National Diet building. And even then, Re-Destro managed to flee. 

He was also a master strategist and tactician, someone who played in the same league as people like Nedzu and Sir Nighteye. It was easy to discount him as a hulking juggernaut (when stressed enough, he turned into a black monster bigger and bulkier than All Might). But he was the last leader of a secret conspiracy that lasted for generations, a conspiracy that embedded itself into the highest ranks of the government, the financial elites and the media. Conspiracy that remained undetected until it was ready to overthrow the government and change society in its image. 

The fact that Re-Destro found pride in knowing every single warrior of the Meta-Liberation Army by his name, face and quirk was probably a cherry on the top. When the coup failed, he met every single MLA unit that lost even a single member to say his condolences. He knew the fallen. He cried for them. He might have lost the coup, but the MLA turned even more fanatically loyal to him on that day. 

HPSC knew about all of that. Just as it knew that the Japanese naval forces were in a position to decimate the MLA forces before landing (unless Geten was with them, then sending anything other than a nuclear missile was just a pointless loss of human life). With the estimated number of landing crafts available to the Meta-Liberation Army it was obvious that no more than twenty thousand warriors could make landfall in one go. 

Northern Battle Group had enough heavy-hitters to hold its ground even if Re-Destro included himself and all of his executives in the first wave. While having enough unranked heroes, soldiers and policemen to decimate the rest. By the time the second wave would be ready, the first one would be massacred. And the HPSC‚Äô reinforcements would begin arriving, to help mop up the survivors. 

The coup changed things - to the better, oddly enough. The Table members within the Northern Battle Group didn‚Äôt raise in arms - the crucial point of Miruko‚Äôs plan was to NOT compromise the security of Japan, after all. What‚Äôs more, the HPSC sent fifty Paragons - including Valiant, the Rank Three Paragon) to reinforce the NBG when the coup ended. After the events of Tartarus battle, the president of the Hero Commission has also made a decision to bolster the Northern Battle Group with every remaining active member and equipment piece of the GSDF. This decision was approved by the government, and the process was underway when the war started.

The HPSC made several crucial miscalculations with that plan. Although, in all honesty, that wasn‚Äôt its fault. They all bottled down to a single thing, in the end. Overhaul. 

No one expected Overhaul to still be alive, despite standing a few meters away from an exploding nuclear bomb. No one expected twenty-five inferior Eclipse copies, boosted with special Trigger, warping twenty-five thousand MLA warriors alongside the twenty-thousand that got there by sea. No one expected close to five hundred A-Rank villains marching alongside the MLA armies (most of what remained from the Tartarus escapees after desertions, hero raids and people simply returning home overseas). No one expected the largest joint deployment of the Inhuman Supremacy Party in history, rising out everywhere throughout northern Japan. No one expected twenty remaining Purified and three remaining Third Gen Noumus. 

The defenders were going to do their best. Like during the Tartarus attack, it wasn‚Äôt going to be enough.

Scream was one of the heroes deep in the Hero Commission‚Äôs pocket. Her screaming attacks were causing collateral damage left and right. They worked differently than Present Mic‚Äôs, they could cut steel when she focused them enough. HPSC was always willing to smooth things out in exchange for‚Ä¶ favors. 

So yes. She was a quote unquote corrupted hero. She did her job, despite that. Stopped villains, saved people. She didn‚Äôt take money from the HPSC, just‚Ä¶. accepted their help when needed. 

Scream saw no issue with that. Normally. Sometimes when she saw people like All Might on the TV, there was‚Ä¶ something like a regret, deep inside her. She was never going to admit that publicly. She refused to admit that to herself. But deep inside she knew it. 

There was no sortie against the MLA landing forces. Reports from the police precincts and hero agencies throughout the northern prefectures made it obvious that they can‚Äôt hope to push Re-Destro armies back to sea. Not with those numbers. 

Before Yoroi Muusha had time to consider retreat south, the vanguard of the MLA (reinforced by the ISP warriors and‚Ä¶ were those the Purified?!) arrived through the warp gates and launched itself against the reinforced walls of the Northern Battle Group headquarters. She could see them from her position on said walls. 

Scream had enough combat experience and knowledge to understand what that meant. PLF and the MLA joined hands. 

The defenders eventually repelled the enemy vanguard after twenty-five minutes of fierce fighting. Scream killed one third gen Noumu, seven Purified and thirty-seven A-Rank villains by herself (she knew that Trigger dose would come in handy at some point). ‚ÄúYou. Your meta-ability is weak.‚Äù Geten (because of course, it had to be that damn asshole) announced. He was standing on an ice bridge, towering over the walls of the headquarters.

‚ÄúWhat‚Äôs the point of that, when your meta-ability is weak?‚Äù Geten replies. Of course, no understanding.

Crust is a dangerous hero. Sure, he has a slightly off-putting and very emotional (both cheerful and sorrowful and everything in-between) personality, but his quirk is no joke. Geten was moving too fast for it to work.

Chapter 58: Paranormal Liberation War [II]

Chapter Text

Day Forty-Six

Niigata has fallen. 

It was, honestly, a given. Even without Geten out there to bulldoze through the defensive ranks of the heroes, the Paranormal Liberation Front had more than enough of firepower left to deal with that city. Heroes had to defend both Niigata and the direct route between Sendai and Tokyo. The latter was significantly more important (which didn‚Äôt stop the Fukushima prefecture from mostly falling to the Paranormal Liberation Front relentless march south).

Worst of all (at least to the heroes), Overhaul got his lab back. He was far behind when it came to Purified production (something happened to his prior lab when he deployed his new body, and he was painfully scarce in details), but he managed to field several false-Getens. Each of them could only use a fraction of the original‚Äôs power, but when boosted with Trigger, they could be‚Ä¶ severely dangerous. And there were also the weakened versions of Re-Destro and the remaining Noumus to consider. 

It was a nasty battle. All Might was nowhere in sight (probably ready to show up if Overhaul or original Re-Destro did), but Captain Celebrity butchered the Overhaul‚Äôs menagerie. His presence was nasty surprise to the Paranormal Liberation Front, since absolutely no one knew why the American Number Two Hero (and he was pretty close to Number One slot, really) suddenly threw himself over the Pacific Ocean to assist Japan when the war started. 

Fun fact - you might be a mini-Geten boosted almost to Geten level of power with lethal doses of Trigger (or similar thing but for a Re-Destro), but you‚Äôll still die when someone drops a cruise ship on your head. Christopher Skyline was eventually forced to retreat, but that was less due to wounds and more due to physical exhaustion and the battle beneath him ending.

While the aerial juggernaut was fighting the PLF monsters, the regular warriors and the A-Rankers (entire platoons of A-Rankers, something essentially unheard of in history) bulldozed through the hero defensive lines on the outskirts of the city.

The Paranormal Liberation War was a conflict unheard of during the modern times. The smartest military minds throughout the world were already observing the events, and the number of international hero and villain groups pitching their support for either side grew steadily. The war was akin to the Spanish Civil War - a massive field experiment for modern military tactics and technologies. 

Rules on not using quirks during the international wars still remained. Nobody wanted people like Endeavor or All Might to become one-man-armies for some international conflicts. Dawn of Quirks and then the era when sufficiently powerful quirk users could easily become warlords and rulers of their own empires were long gone and nobody really wanted their return. But knowing what MIGHT have happened if those rules were thrown out of the window was a potentially useful thing. 

And this war‚Ä¶ It was technically a villain insurgency according to international law. Rules were lax.

Paranormal Liberation War proved that heroes on such a battlefield were, in the end, something akin to late middle ages knights. Powerful and unstoppable forces of nature (especially those stronger ones) but ultimately too unruly and lacking discipline. Capable of conquering an area, but faring much worse in holding it. 

Heroes and villains battled it out, but it was the GSDF (with some police reinforcements) and the regular MLA warriors (and QLF soldiers) that held the ground. Majority of skirmishes and smaller battles were waged by those forces, with heroes and villains playing the role of tanks or fighter jets. Something to establish superiority or help in rooting out resistance, but needing support to actually capture and hold something. 

Villains thus far triumphed. Mostly by the virtue of too many heroes being forced to stay behind the frontline to guard their towns from warp-raids, which meant that the villains had numerical superiority over the heroes. The fact that MLA had several times the numbers (and training) of the reestablished GSDF was a major contributing factor. 

Every battle thus far ended with far greater casualties on the PLF side. Every captured town forced the PLF to garrison it. Their superiority in numbers was going to be a fleeting thing, and trying to capture and hold a city as large as Tokyo was going to be a nightmare. 

Their numbers on the frontline were whittled down further after the League of Villains decided to say goodbye to Dabi in their own way and launched a warp-gate raid on Sendai that ended with almost two thousand PLF warriors dead, wounded or gone. Gremlin took down their communication network, Kurogiri warped bombs into several major buildings and the League as a whole spent seven hours hunting for survivors before the Overhaul‚Äôs general staff noticed what was happening in the city and warped in reinforcements. 

Directly into a minefield (made by Gremlin). Covered by the second Mustard‚Äôs poison gas cyclone, with incendiary rounds falling from the skies, courtesy of the Quirkless Equality Movement. 

Someone stole out the PLF plans for deploying reinforcements to that city in case of the League's raid from the PLF headquarters on Hokkaido. Overhaul raged for days. 

Heroes could still slow down the PLF‚Äôs advance more, but they were, in the end, at least partially celebrities, trained to avoid collateral damage. Not hardened soldiers. They, as a whole, still prefered to take the enemy's prisoners if possible. And preferred to retreat (like Sendai and Niigata proved) instead of trying to grind the enemy into a stalemate by warfare of attrition in a place filled with civilians. In both cases the defenders retreated once the line of defense on the city outskirts was broken. 

 

***

Day Forty-Seven

Chitose Kizuki has a nice day. 

She is the executive director of Shoowaysha Publishing, and one of the most famous journalists in Japan. The war offered a lot of interesting scoops. And the Paranormal Liberation Front was winning it - a crucial thing for someone who (under the codename of Curious) was secretly lieutenant of the Meta-Liberation Army. 

She just finished writing a new article. One subtly questioning the way the current leadership of Japan was handling the current crisis. Something to undermine the war effort without making it obvious that she was in any way connected to Re-Destro. The rest of her company gravitated towards slightly similar political positions, but she did her best to make it appear natural, and in a way connected to the MLA. 

She even made a notable steps to curb quirk-discrimination within her company on two occasions when one of her journalists did something‚Ä¶ too‚Ä¶ rash. Everyone bought it. She was seen as a champion of equality by some, oddly enough. 

She is about to send the article when someone enters her office. 

One of her interns. He asks some rather meaningless questions about his current work. She does her best to appear concerned, when suddenly she feels a slight pinch in her shoulder. 

She looked down to see‚Ä¶ was that a dart?

Curious feels her quirk vanishing from her. Then she sees the pistol in the intern‚Äôs hand. Her mind connects the dots. Her hand rushes towards a well hidden alarm button, but the intern lunges forward and nails her hand to the desk with a knife. 

It was a deception. Her other hand hits the real panic button. But she hears no alarm going off. Her bodyguards don‚Äôt rush inside. Did someone switch her security off? Her office is mostly soundproofed, because she likes to work in peace and quiet, she can‚Äôt just shout for help and...

‚ÄúSurprise!‚Äù The intern laughs and its face warps into that of a yellow-haired girl. ‚ÄúGremlin hacked your security. No help is coming! And all the recording devices in this room just rolled belly-up on us.‚Äù

Day Sixty-Four

CRC and ISP bases were mostly located by the sixtieth day of the war. Four days later the reckoning came.
